question: A.002 [1.0 point] (2.0) Which ONE of the following is the MAIN reason for operating with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. Increased neutron efficiency since thermal neutrons are less likely to leak out of the core than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: b. Neutron absorption in non fuel material increases exponentially as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: c. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal energy neutrons than fast neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: d. Moderator temperature coefficient becomes positive as neutron energy increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: b. possesses thermal rather than kinetic energy.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 2-36, 2-45.

answers.answer: c. has been produced several seconds after its initiating fission occurred.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 2-36, 2-45.

answers.answer: d. experiences no net change in its energy after several collisions with atoms of the diffusing medium.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 2-36, 2-45.

question: A.010 [1.0 point] (10.0) The RESONANCE ESCAPE PROBABILITY is defined as a ratio of:

answers.answer: a. the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel over the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel and core materials.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1, page 3-16.

answers.answer: b. the number of fast neutrons produced by fission in a generation over the number of total neutrons produced by fission in the previous generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1, page 3-16.

answers.answer: c. the number of fast neutrons produced by U-238 over the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1, page 3-16.

answers.answer: d. the number of neutrons that reach thermal energy over the number of fast neutrons that start to slow down.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1, page 3-16.

question: A.017 [1.0 point] (17.0) Which of the following statements is true about Xenon following a reactor scram?

answers.answer: a. The concentration of 135 Xe will decrease due to reduced nuclear flux
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Following a reactor shutdown, xenon-135 concentration will increase due to the decay of the iodine inventory of the core. DOE Handbook, Vol. 2, Section 4

answers.answer: b. The concentration of 135 Xe will decrease by natural decay into 135 I
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Following a reactor shutdown, xenon-135 concentration will increase due to the decay of the iodine inventory of the core. DOE Handbook, Vol. 2, Section 4

answers.answer: c. The concentration of 135 Xe will increase due to the decay of the 135 I inventory.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Following a reactor shutdown, xenon-135 concentration will increase due to the decay of the iodine inventory of the core. DOE Handbook, Vol. 2, Section 4

answers.answer: d. The concentration of 135 Xe will remain constant until it is removed via neutron burnout during the subsequent reactor startup.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Following a reactor shutdown, xenon-135 concentration will increase due to the decay of the iodine inventory of the core. DOE Handbook, Vol. 2, Section 4
